Title: ESG & Financial Wellbeing at RBC
About: Elvis is an entrepreneur working towards a more financially healthy Canada.

Previous Experience.Description:
A.T. Kearney is a global management consulting firm operating in over 40 countries, with clients comprising major private, public & non-profit organizations. 

Elvis worked on everything from real-time payments in the US to healthcare strategy in Canada to operations optimization for a global ink distributor.

IFH Lab (previously Innovate Financial Health) is a program for startups dedicated to improving the financial health of financially vulnerable Canadians. 

We have worked with 12 startups across two cohorts. Since the launch of our program, alumni have raised over $50 mn in additional capital, helped tens of thousands of Canadians, and added 50+ jobs. Partners include JPMorgan Chase, Meridian, Canadian Bankers Association, Progressa, Fasken, Capital One, the City of Toronto, and more. 

In January 2021, Innovate Financial Health was acquired by Montreal-based non-profit Fintech Cadence. 

https://fintechcadence.com/ifhlab/

Social Capital Partners is an independently-funded non-profit that tackles important social problems by developing creative and high-risk solutions. 

Elvis led SCP's work with the Royal Society of Arts in launching the inaugural Future Work Awards for 34 innovative solutions from around the world focused on helping workers deal with the changing nature of work. Elvis worked at SCP while raising funding for Innovate Financial Health. 

Elvis also conducted research to test SCP's newest ideas on tackling wealth inequality from catalyzing small business starts to enabling employees ownership. 

www.socialcapitalpartners.ca

Previous Experience.Role: Senior Manager, Sustainability & Enterprise ESG Strategy

Posts.Text:
Sharing some personal news - After almost 4 years of building IFH Lab by Fintech Cadence from an idea to a pilot to a long-standing program now integrated with Fintech Cadence, I decided earlier this month to pursue a new opportunity and to pass the baton to Molly Willats, Layial El-Hadi, and the rest of the Fintech Cadence team. 

I'm incredibly proud of all the work we've accomplished over the past few years in building an ecosystem of startups, non-profits, investors, financial institutions, and experts all dedicated to advancing technology solutions that improve the financial lives of Canadians. Our first two cohorts of 12 startups have already collectively raised an additional $11 million, added 60+ jobs, and have helped well over 25,000 Canadians. These solutions are helping newcomers build credit, temporary foreign workers remit money safely, freelancers access appropriate insurance, employees get earned wages on demand, low-income Canadians start emergency funds, and more. I can't wait to see what the 2022 cohort has in store! 

I'm also proud of all the work we've accomplished with the broader Fintech Cadence team including the recent announcement of $400,000 in funding for the newly publicized Fintech Hub program. It was such a pleasure working with the full Fintech Cadence team and thank you for welcoming Molly and me with open arms. On that note, a special shout-out goes to Molly Willats for being a part of this journey from the beginning - I'm incredibly excited and confident that you'll be taking over and can't wait to see how you continue shaping the program and the mission we've talked about so many times. 

To the hundred-plus startups, advisors, partners, and funders that have supported me on this journey, I want to sincerely thank all of you for all the time, advice, and investment you generously provided to support my vision. There are too many of you to shout out here today but I appreciate all the kind notes and emails of everyone that has reached out already. 

As many of you know, this work all started from an initial research question at the MaRS Discovery District Studio Y program - "How do we use technology to improve financial inclusion in Canada?" In many ways, that is still the question driving me today and I'm excited to announce that I've decided to join RBC's Sustainability & Enterprise ESG strategy team to focus on topics like financial wellness, affordable housing, and wealth inequality. 

I'm still staying in this space so I'm excited to continue working with all of you to move the conversation forward. 

Elvis

The IFH Lab by Fintech Cadence is now accepting applications for our 3rd cohort and we couldn’t be more thrilled! 🎉

We have watched the startups from our past cohorts take growth by the horns since graduating - across the 12 startups from 2020 and 2021 they’ve raised $11M+, added 50+ people to their teams and helped over 25,000 Canadians.  🇨🇦

To say we’re proud of their success would be an understatement. And now it’s your chance to join the IFH Lab community! The IFH Lab by Fintech Cadence mission has always been to support founders who are tackling the financial challenges, big and small, that are holding millions of Canadians back from achieving financial health and resilience. We also believe that fintech has the potential to address systemic barriers for consumers and communities who are systematically underserved and excluded from accessing mainstream financial products and services for a variety of reasons; like low-wage and gig-workers, seniors, new-immigrants to Canada, indigenous peoples, renters, and small business owners. 

We particularly welcome applications from founders tackling the specific challenges faced by these and other marginalized or excluded groups, and with lived experience of these issues. 2022 brings some exciting updates to the IFH Lab program that we can’t wait to share with you. We’re pleased to be moving back to a hybrid format with some in-person elements that will give our teams the opportunity to learn in-person from each other and our experts.

Original Post.Text:
Climate change is impacting Canadians and people around the world, so it feels timely for Financial Resilience Institute to publish our latest Intelligence Memo and video on the intersection between climate change and household financial vulnerability and financial stress. https://lnkd.in/g7tB54rJ

Over 1 in 5 households in Canada report they have been negatively impacted by extreme weather events over the past 12 to 24 months as of February 2023, with a clear association between this and increased household financial vulnerability and financial stress. There are knock-on impacts on the physical health, emotional health, productivity and engagement of Canadians and future generations, with more financially vulnerable households being disproportionately impacted by financial vulnerability and financial hardship for those experiencing extreme weather events. Protection, information and access-to-help gaps are evident from the Canadian household perspective.

This research levers data and analytics from the Institute’s peer-reviewed Financial Resilience Index model and February 2023, June 2022 and June 2021 data, based on a sample size of over 5000 households. 

Many thanks to Vancity for their leadership in working with us to investigate this intersection starting back in 2021 and for allowing us to include analytics on their members and British Columbians, published in their 2022 Climate Change Report. This paper also cites and recognizes the excellent research, advocacy, and thought leadership of  Canadian Climate Institute / Institut climatique du Canada.

Please reach out if you have any questions or comments on this research paper created by our team. And kudos recognition to all leaders and organizations who are working tirelessly to help build a more resilient sustainable world.

#financialresilience #climate #resilience

Original Post.Text:
The 7th Index release from the Institute's Financial Resilience Index model highlights the Canada's mean financial resilience score is 51.24 as of February 2023. 

This is similar to the June 2022 Index, which is interesting and somewhat surprising, given the inflationary environment and higher interest rates. Index data shows that Canadians are working hard from a behavioural perspective to maintain or improve their financial resilience, with 70% of Canadians having significantly reduced their non-essential expenses (up significantly from 56% in June 2022), despite 84% reporting that the increase in the cost of living has outpaced any income growth for their household. Disciplined spending and savings behaviours are showing up through very slightly improved household savings rates at the national level, in turn impacting the liquid savings buffer and confidence in the ability to meet short-term savings goal Index indicators. It’s expected that some of the affordability programs (as well as changed behaviours) may also be helping to offset financial stress indicators - and contribute to the slight decrease in ‘Extremely Vulnerable’ households (from 21% in June 2022 to 18% in February 2023). All told, big picture, financial vulnerability continues to be a mainstream issue affecting 20 million households (or 78% of the population) with financial vulnerability spanning all household income demographics. Those able to exhibit healthy financial behaviours over the longer term have higher financial resilience. But financial stress and financial vulnerability continue to negatively impact the physical health and well-being of many, tracked through the Index since 2017.

We continue to see nuances in household financial resilience by province and for different populations, with Quebec and B.C. being the most financially resilient provinces as of February 2023. Women continue to have a mean financial resilience score that is 4 points lower than men. Challenges and inequities are exacerbated for  'Extremely Vulnerable' and ‘Financially Vulnerable’ (with financial resilience scores under 50); renters, mortgage-holders and those struggling with debt; low-income households and single parents; those lacking social capital, impacted by unplanned life events and/or facing systemic barriers. While 37% of Canadians overall have a negative or zero household savings rate as of February 2023, this is the case for 88% of 'Extremely Vulnerable' Canadians with 88% experiencing significant financial hardship compared to just 3% of 'Financially Resilient' households.

More data and insights will be in the Institute Subscriber Report on April 28th at my TABE presentation to Economists on April 4, 2023.
 
The February Index is based on 5010 adult Canadians from a representative sample of the population by household income, province, age and gender. The peer-reviewed Index has a pre-pandemic baseline of February 2020. More info is available at: https://lnkd.in/g5A6zcFx

It's been a while since I posted a comprehensive update on what we've been up to at Moves. So here it goes:

First of all, our team is on a shipping tear! Without fail, every Monday I start my day with release notes of what our product and engineering teams have put into production for our members. 

In one year, we've gone from being a feature-limited banking product for gig workers to a comprehensive business management dashboard, reward program, best in-class banking product, performant cash advance service, and more.

Moves members can now:
- Generate annual income reports
- Summarize expenses by category
- Label between personal and business use
- Instantly benefit from emergency cash advances, with multiple options for speed of repayment
- Earn fractional stock rewards every time they use their Moves account
- Set weekly earning goals
- Compare profitability across 20+ apps they might work for daily
- Instantly fund and withdraw money to/from their account to/from any other debit card
- Deposit checks on mobile

And there's a lot more coming between now and the end of the year. I couldn't be more proud of the velocity and quality our team has been able to consistently maintain.

All in all, Moves will be the most complete gig worker toolset in the market by 2024.

In parallel to these huge product changes, we're also making significant strides in how we acquire new members. Although we're still actively experimenting, our go-to-market strategy is really humming right now. 

Members are coming to Moves through a variety of channels, but we're seeing most success from: 
- Organic/SEO web traffic (a massive positive for PMF)
- Gig economy influencers on YouTube
- A member referral program

Our team also had the incredible privilege of participating in a unique event called GigCon in Denver Colorado. We spent time with gig workers, YouTubers, policy makers, and partner companies. Moves made a huge splash under the banner of "Gig Work is Real Work" - a slogan that so articulately captures our reason for being.

I'm excited for the changes coming in Q4 and incredibly optimistic about 2024 and beyond.

Yesterday I had the distinct pleasure of speaking on the Startup and Tech panel at the 25th annual APEX Conference along with Aadil K., founder and CEO of Swyft. 

We talked about how we got started on our path into tech and entrepreneurship, the idea of leaving a legacy, and the importance of purpose, amongst other things.

Preparing for the panel was a wonderful way to start 2023 - I realized that I don't often take the time to reflect on where I have been, what I have achieved, and how much progress I really have made. In thinking about what I could possibly have to say to a group of business and STEM students as someone with a background in neither, I confronted head on the imposter syndrome that has been a near constant companion since I first started working in fintech as a social science nerd with a background in Geography. 

But as I sat with the questions we had been sent to prepare, I realized that I have been at the ground level of a startup. That I have a tremendous amount to be proud of in the work that Elvis Wong and I did building IFH Lab by Fintech Cadence. I realized that through three cohorts of supporting founders in their own journeys, I had a legitimate place on the stage. It was surreal to feel for the first time like I shouldn't be in the audience this time. 

Thank you to Mirna Henary and the organizing team at Apex for inviting Fintech Cadence to take part, and for the moment of personal and professional reflection to kick off my new year.

#professionalgrowth #techcareers #newyearbetterme

Today is a very proud day for me. Today a group of inspiring Canadian leaders have come together to put their full weight behind strong employee ownership policy in Canada.

It has been enormously gratifying to see how many people have put up their hands to engage in this effort over the past two years. Not just to say "hey, this is a great idea" but to say "how can I help." Today, that help has become very real.

This group that's now over 60 strong isn't just advocating for any EOT policy. Our Call for Action is insisting on a strong, fulsome policy including tax incentives and a requirement that benefits go to all employees of a company, at no cost to them. This is based on the years of experience from the US and the UK - only with a policy like this will employee ownership in Canada scale quickly and deliver the inclusive wealth it's proven capable of in those countries.

Anything less will be a massive missed opportunity. As baby boomer business owners retire, there are 140,000 Canadian companies employing almost 5 million workers that are the right target size for sale to an EOT. 

You will hear more from me and from the Canadian Employee Ownership Coalition over the next few months in the lead-up to Budget 2023. We look forward to your engagement and always appreciate the support of this community. It certainly feels very real today.

#cdnpoli

Post Details.Text:
I am glad Colin Deacon got to this before me, as he wrote a much more thoughtful takedown of Andrew Willis 's column than I would have. 

It is so disheartening to see the Globe act as a mouthpiece for Canada's business elite, when they've done such a good job of hiring young reporters who are willing to put in the effort to build a more balanced view of the Canadian economy. The old guard remains, though, and remains enamoured with the oligopolistic economy built by Canada's wealthiest families. 

Andrew's next column might be about Canada's mysterious productivity problems, and yet he likely won't connect the two things. If you want to change a system you won't win every case, and Matthew Boswell has been willing to take important risks on behalf of all of us. To the old guard, that's just not polite or deferential enough for the Canada they were brought up in. 

Good on you, Senator, for continuing to be a voice for a more innovative, dynamic and competitive economy.

Post Details.Text:
Wrapped an incredible internship at BCG X’s New York office last week! 
I spent the summer with the Venture Architecture chapter, learning the ropes of corporate venture building from Jake Medina and Justine W. on projects with the potential to reshape the future of American healthcare. 

What is a Venture Architect, you may ask? It’s a role that defies convention. Tactically, this person owns the business success of a venture. This summer I supported my teams in defining business models, mapping markets, and drafting investment cases. More than that, though, Venture Architects are creative, re-imagining how a business can and should be designed from the ground up. It’s felt like a perfect marriage of my experiences in early-stage startups, venture capital, and now, business school.

As I ramp up for the second year of my MBA at The Wharton School, I’m excited to dive deeper into the subjects that emerged from this experience, enrolling in Behavioural Health and Innovation classes for the upcoming semester 🩺

A huge thank you to the entire BCG X team for the opportunity, excited to stay in touch! 😇

Reactions.Contact Role: Investing in frontier tech @ Golden

Post Details.Text:
I’m thrilled to announce that I’ve joined Golden Ventures as a Principal, focused on researching and leading investments in emerging technology companies.

From the beginning of my venture career, supporting founders has always been priority #1. Rolling up my sleeves outside of boards to assist on financial and operational matters, project managing R&D engagements, and helping founders strategize on launching new businesses gave me a strong desire to turn to the operating side to amplify my impact at IEX. Now, I’m excited to take the zero-to-one lessons learned during my time there back to the institutional side of venture to invest in world-changing companies at the earliest stages, alongside the best team I could ask for.

At Georgian, I gravitated towards “frontier” technologies from a research, thesis-building and investing perspective, with a specific focus on Applied AI and web3. For the past year and a half, I had the opportunity to build out IEX’s venture arm, and help launch new businesses being built at the bleeding edge of the digital assets landscape. I am forever grateful to Bradley Katsuyama, CEO and co-founder of IEX, as well as my mentor and friend, for his endless support and trust.

Golden is a firm I’ve known by reputation for my entire career. Whenever I talked to friends (Jamie Rosenblatt), founders (Yevgeniy Vahlis), LPs (Ian Carew), or other VCs (Karamdeep Nijjar), several key themes emerged and deeply resonated with me: full-stack founder support, radical candor and unyielding commitment to the craft of investing.

Thank you to Matt Golden, Ameet Shah, and the entire Golden family for giving me this incredible opportunity to continue building our franchise.

Lastly, my cross-context exposure to frontier technologies has helped me create an overarching framework / thesis focused on sustainable value creation within the Generative AI and Web3 landscapes, and I’m excited to share and continue building on it with colleagues, founders and friends in these spaces. I’ll be publishing a series of blog posts that articulate my vision for sustainable value creation in AI at the application, tooling and infrastructure layers.

To any emerging / deep tech founders (and VCs) in my network, let’s talk!

CC: Bert Amato, Alison Kaizer, Julia Baird, Emma Cumuric, Mark Lahn

Post Details.Text:
It's been said that building a business isn't a straight line. The ups and downs of building a start-up have been the most challenging and rewarding chapters of my life. Like a rollercoaster, the intensity of feeling has run the gamut - stomach-turning, eye-closed, blood-pumping fear and excitement.

Lucky for me, I've had the great fortune of working with an amazing team (Mark Levitan, Karen Radic, Caitlin Carter, Tanya Romanuk, Joseph Petralito, Sumit Garg), who get up every day and strap in for the ride. Emotional highs, down-turns, and dips - burning the midnight oil has been part & parcel of this entrepreneurial journey. 

But we're winning. Gaining momentum. 

We're doing hard things that not only create impact for our clients, but are changing the status quo. And, despite a very broken market of high interest lenders, payday loans and credit counselling companies, we've created a product that offers our customers hope. 

We like to say that Parachute is a loan with purpose - and for me, it's personal. 
I am our client - a kid who 30 years ago (with a commerce degree!) found himself on the other side of a failed business, bad advice, and declaring bankruptcy. A poor financial decision that followed me throughout my career. 
But there's no shame in that - or at least there shouldn't be - and that's why Parachute was created. We offer the canopy to help Canadians land on their financial feet. 

I want to thank our friends at Intuit for sharing my story with their community. It offers a little background as to why I do this - and hopefully, it's a little reminder that together we can get financially well. (www.myparachute.co)

After an incredible journey spanning more than 7 wonderful years in Canada, the time has come for me to embark on a new chapter in my life. With a mix of excitement and nostalgia, I'm thrilled to announce that I'll be returning to Sydney.

My time in Toronto has been nothing short of remarkable. The vibrant city, the welcoming people, and the countless professional experiences have enriched my life in ways I could never have imagined. Working alongside so
many talented individuals has been an honor and a privilege, and I'm deeply
grateful for the collaborative spirit that has defined my years here while being at RFI Global, Payments Canada and Peoples Group.

As I prepare to make the move to Sydney, I'll be carrying with me cherished memories, lifelong friendships, and a wealth of knowledge gained during my tenure in Canada. While the distance might grow, my connections and
enthusiasm for this incredible country remain unwavering. I'll be cheering for
Canada from down under, continuing to push for its innovation journey, staying engaged with the happenings in this dynamic nation that has become a second home.

Please rest assured that this is not a goodbye, but merely a "see you later." Let's stay connected and continue to inspire and support each other in our respective journeys. 

Thank you, Canada, for embracing me and contributing to a chapter of my life that will forever hold a special place in my heart. To my colleagues, mentors, and friends (I can’t name you all, otherwise Linkedin will collapse!) — thank you for being part of this remarkable adventure.

As I look towards new horizons, I'm excited to explore the opportunities that await me in Sydney. Here's to embracing change, chasing dreams, and making a positive impact no matter where life takes us.

Wishing you all the best in your endeavors, and until we meet again!

Reactions.Contact Role: VP People & Culture - PolicyMe I Ex-Deloitte

Post Details.Text:
Today marks my 2 year anniversary at PolicyMe. 🎉 

The saying 'time flies when you are having fun / doing what you love' definitely applies here.

However, at the same time, it feels like 10 years.

Leading HR at a scaling start-up is frankly a ton of work. This is partly because of the sheer volume of things to do and partly because of how much I care.

Over the last 2 years I have overseen the process for:
- Every human we hired
- Every performance review we've ran
- Every engagement survey we've sent out
- Every difficult conversation we've needed to have
- Every structuring discussion and decision
- and so much more

Building PolicyMe has truly been one of my most rewarding career experiences thus far.

If you are looking to move into People & Culture at a start-up, my biggest piece of advise is two fold:

(1) Find a founding team you truly believe in

(2) Find a product or company that you think has very real market potential

This makes our jobs so much easier.

A big shoutout to Laura McKay, Andrew Ostro and Jeff McKay for trusting me to own People & Culture. And another big shoutout to Lavita Mascarenhas and Allison Cribbs, the best and mightiest People team I could have asked for.

Here is to many more! 🍾

87% of women in Canada want financial help, yet 70% are unsatisfied with current offerings. As a runner-up in the "Best Fintech Pilot by a For-profit Organisation" at the 2023 MAIAs, Untangle Money is changing the game.

By focusing on unique challenges women face and providing tailored financial plans, Untangle Money is ensuring women don't fall short in retirement.

Reactions.Contact Role: Co-founder & CEO at online will platform Willful *On maternity leave until January 2024*

Post Details.Text:
I’m embarking on my 2nd maternity leave from Willful, with another little girl scheduled to join our family in early September. 

I took my first 4-month leave in late 2021 after our daughter Emmy was born - it was the first time I had stepped away from Willful after going all-in with Kevin on his vision, and it was scary - both because I’m a Type A person who has always defined myself by my career; but also because it meant testing out whether I was “needed but not necessary” in the business. Thankfully our amazing COO Julia Wilkie stepped in to manage things while I was away, and the team excelled - and I got to keep my finger on the pulse, chatting with Julia regularly and participating in team events like our Dragons’ Den viewing party and our holiday party.

This time I feel even more confident stepping away for a few months - Julia is taking the reins again, and I can’t think of anyone more well-equipped to run the company while I’m away. We have an incredibly talented leadership team, including our CTO Matt & CRO Dave, and a wider team of 20 people who will move our mission forward. And thankfully we’ve built a flexible, autonomous virtual culture driven by values like empathy and empowerment which supports bringing our full selves to work. I’ve never felt judged for expanding our family (by our investors, our board, our team, or any other stakeholders).

When I was preparing for my first mat leave, I spoke to so many other parents in tech who gave me amazing advice. I pulled all of it into a BetaKit article, which I hope has helped other expecting parents pull together their plans. A few of the top pieces of advice based on my leaves:
- Don’t set a return date before you go! You don’t know how you’ll react to being a new parent, and you want to leave things fluid for your return 
- Have your transition plan ready before your due date…I learned this the hard way when our first daughter arrived 9 days early and I was scrambling to finish things from the hospital
- Ensure you explore which government benefits you’re eligible for well in advance (especially if you own over 40% of your company, or you don’t pay into EI)
- Set boundaries for yourself! I knew if I didn’t hand over my inbox to our virtual assistant Amanda and delete Slack from my phone I wouldn’t truly step away

Jobs.Title: Associate Director, CUSO Market Risk
Jobs.Description:
Come Work with Us!
At RBC, our culture is deeply supportive and rich in opportunity and reward. You will help our clients thrive and our communities prosper, empowered by a spirit of shared purpose.
Whether you’re helping clients find new opportunities, developing new technology, or providing expert advice to internal partners, you will be doing work that matters in the world, in an environment built on teamwork, service, responsibility, diversity, and integrity.
Job Title
Associate Director, CUSO Market Risk
Job Description
Risk Oversight and Analytics
Run /oversee market risk reporting for the US Legal Entities and ensure the accuracy of key risk measurements and compliance to market risk limits. Analyze key trading strategies and products to ensure they are in line with CUSO risk tolerance and objectives.Investigate risks to provide value-added insight and analysis to senior management on risk trends and concerns.Review risks so they are compliant with local regulators requirements and enterprise policies.
Market Risk Regulatory Capital 
Ensure the completeness and accuracy of the scope for US Market Risk Regulatory calculation, implementing effective controls to capture covered positions across businesses / entities within the RIHC.Lead the VaR Backtesting, VaR Risk Factors Monitoring and other processes which support the Value at Risk (VaR) models framework used for RIHC regulatory capital calculation Key person for implementation of FRTB for the RIHC, leading the implementation of US specific requirements and enhancements to RBC FRTB framework.
Compliance

Jobs.Title: 2024 Capital Markets, Global Investment Banking Summer Associate
Jobs.Description:
Come Work with Us!
At RBC, our culture is deeply supportive and rich in opportunity and reward. You will help our clients thrive and our communities prosper, empowered by a spirit of shared purpose.
Whether you’re helping clients find new opportunities, developing new technology, or providing expert advice to internal partners, you will be doing work that matters in the world, in an environment built on teamwork, service, responsibility, diversity, and integrity.
Job Title
2024 Capital Markets, Global Investment Banking Summer Associate
Job Description
Global Investment Banking Summer Associate – Houston
What is the opportunity?
RBC Capital Markets is a premier investment bank that provides a focused set of products and services to corporations, institutional investors and governments around the world. With more than 7,100 professionals, we operate out of 70 offices in 15 countries across North America, the U.K., Europe, and the Asia-Pacific region.
We work with clients in over 100 countries around the world to deliver the expertise and execution required to raise capital, access markets, mitigate risk and acquire or dispose of assets. We are consistently ranked among the largest global investment banks according to Bloomberg and Dealogic.
RBC Capital Markets is part of a leading provider of financial services, Royal Bank of Canada (RBC). Operating since 1869, RBC is one of the top 15 largest banks in the world and the fifth largest in North America, as measured by market capitalization. With a strong capital base and consistent financial performance, RBC is among a small group of highly rated global banks.
RBCCM U.S. Summer Associate Program
Each year, we invite rising second-year MBA students to join our Global Investment Banking (GIB) platform for a 10-week U.S. Summer Associate Program. The program provides an opportunity for you to experience the culture and atmosphere of RBC Capital Markets and experience the role of a full-time Associate.
What will you do?
GIB provides a complete suite of strategic advisory services, as well as equity and debt capital raising capabilities for leading corporations, institutions and governments. Our Houston office recruits for the Energy industry group.
Similar to full-time GIB Associates, Summer Associates will spend their time:
Working on a variety of live transactions and client-facing business development initiatives in all areas of GIBDeveloping and preserving complex financial modelsContributing to the delivery of client meetings and presentationsConducting research to analyze market trendsResearching and analyzing future opportunities
What do you need to succeed?
In selecting Summer Associates, we look for the following:
Students in their penultimate year of study at an accredited 2-year MBA program2+ years’ work post-undergraduate work experienceAbility to manage multiple competing priorities and thrive in a fast-paced and challenging environmentValue and possess strong competency in the following behaviors: Collaboration, Relationship Building, Communication, Integrity and Operating with Diverse and Inclusive MindsetWell-rounded set of interests and extra-curricular activities beyond academics
What’s in it for you?
We thrive on the challenge to be our best, think progressively, continue our growth, and deliver trusted advice to help our clients thrive and communities prosper. We care about each other, reaching our individual/collective potential, making a difference to our communities, and achieving success that is mutual.
From this experience you would gain:
A strong foundation in fundamental investment banking skills such as financial modeling and analysis, transaction execution and negotiation, and in-depth industry/product knowledgeA better understanding of RBC’s products and servicesThe support of a mentor (typically a full-time Associate or Vice President)An opportunity to network and discuss career opportunities through a number of social events
Inclusion and Equal Opportunity Employment
RBC is an equal opportunity employer committed to diversity and inclusion. We are pleased to consider all qualified applicants for employment without regard to race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, age, disability, protected veterans status, Aboriginal/Native American status or any other legally-protected factors. Disability-related accommodations during the application process are available upon request.

PRINCIPAL RESPONSIBILITIES - GOVERNANCE
This role is responsible for the active management of governance activities for the U.S. Risk Office, including the development of board and senior management reporting.Corporate Secretary for CUSO RMC responsible for setting the agenda, taking meeting minutes, and collect, validate and distribute meeting materials.Work closely with SGO to set the agenda for the Risk Committee meeting, communicate the agenda and Risk Committee materials to CUSO senior management, Board reporting, new policies, amendments to existing policies and providing support on policy practices to the Businesses and other Corporate Support Segments as appropriate, and for meeting GRM Enterprise Policy requirements.Prepare, present and steer governance materials through the approval process with Senior Management and committees such as the CUSO Risk Management Committee (CUSO RMC) and the Risk Committee of RBC U.S. Group Holdings, LLC.Establish and maintain board reporting standards, communicate these standards to CUSO employees and work with CUSO the ensure compliance with these standards.Review and interpret FRB, OCC and other applicable regulatory guidance, and advice on their impact to RBC.

Jobs.Description:
Come Work with Us!
At RBC, our culture is deeply supportive and rich in opportunity and reward. You will help our clients thrive and our communities prosper, empowered by a spirit of shared purpose.
Whether you’re helping clients find new opportunities, developing new technology, or providing expert advice to internal partners, you will be doing work that matters in the world, in an environment built on teamwork, service, responsibility, diversity, and integrity.
Job Title
Compliance Analyst
Job Description
What is the opportunity?
As Compliance Analyst, you are accountable for the administration of RBC Enterprise personal trading policy internal control framework with respect to information barriers, personal trading and conflicts of interest. You will conduct monitoring and testing as assigned, identify potential conflicts of interest and escalate to management as required. You will also develop and maintain strong working relationships with business management in order to adequately support the business.
What will you do?
Administer the Capital Markets and Enterprise Personal Trading Policy, by ensuring that employees newly identified as being subject to the program are (a) correctly categorized (eg. subject to RBC windows, other trading restrictions, required to pre-clear, required to bring personal and related person accounts to approved dealer), and (b) apprised of and perform their responsibilities under the policy. This includes collecting the Employee Disclosure Forms when employees are made subject to the policy and the annual refreshmentAdminister the policy and make recommendations to Control Room management regarding conflicts of interest arising from personal trading, outside business activities and private investments and ensure that appropriate records are maintainedServe as main point of contact on Business Unit Coordinator and employee enquiries regarding personal tradingPre-clear employee tradesDistribute Employee Disclosure Form to RBC and RBCCM new hires/transfers; act as employee facilitator; respond to queries; follow-up with non-respondents; and escalate to management or department heads as necessaryAssist with surveillance of personal trading as applicable under Control Room policies and procedureRecommend process and design enhancements within responsibilities, including leveraging new technology whenever possibleProviding back up support for other employees within Compliance.Deal with IT issues regarding the control room technology system (e.g. functionality of a page, identify enhancements required, etc.)Field questions from RBC and RBCCM employees and unit coordinators, and assist with the maintenance of CREM data on employee profiles
What do you need to succeed? 
Must-have
2+ years of experience in the financial services industryDemonstrated knowledge of applicable regulatory and internal policy requirements, and all others as applicableAbility to work and flourish in a fast-paced environmentUniversity degree or equivalent educationAbility to work independently, managing various high priorities
Nice-to-have 
Securities industry related courses and qualifications are a key asset

Jobs.Title: Associate Director, Quantitative Methodology
Jobs.Description:
Come Work with Us!
At RBC, our culture is deeply supportive and rich in opportunity and reward. You will help our clients thrive and our communities prosper, empowered by a spirit of shared purpose.
Whether you’re helping clients find new opportunities, developing new technology, or providing expert advice to internal partners, you will be doing work that matters in the world, in an environment built on teamwork, service, responsibility, diversity, and integrity.
Job Title
Associate Director, Quantitative Methodology
Job Description
Support methodologies related to market risk management for trading or banking portfolios. This includes the specification, implementation, performance monitoring and maintenance of these methodologies. Methodology Development and Documentation: Support market risk methodology (a.k.a ‘models’) development and implementation for trading products, including vanilla bond, agency MBS, ABS, CLO, CMBS and RMBS. Market risk methodologies include, but not limited to, VaR and SVaR models based on historical simulation, statistical analysis for financial data, as well as Market Risk RWA projection. Develop computer program to implement the methodology or test methodology soundness. Act familiar with pricing models for vanilla bond, Agency MBS, ABS, CLO, including multi-factor interest rate model, prepayment model etc. Know vendor system and data for trading products, such as Polypaths, CDO net, Markit. Provide risk modeling transparency. Methodology Maintenance and Monitoring: Remediate model issues from internal validation, internal audit as well as external regulators. Re-submit model white papers on regular basis with portfolio and model features update. Work on the maintenance the existing models. This includes ensuring adequate review of the assumptions on an ongoing basis, timely calibration of the models and monitoring of model limitations. Coordinate with internal stake holders and external regulators: Work with local market risk and front office to coordinate and resolve model related issues for market risk methodologies of trading products. Interact with market data team to ensure the accuracy and completeness of the market data used to support the various models. Market data is a key underlying component for all key risk models and is accordingly a critical area of focus BAU risk management. The work related to market data will involve a significant amount of effort and change in order to comply with the Regulatory expectations. Interact with regulators regarding methodology analysis for market risk. Provide comprehensive explanation of the VaR and SVaR results to the risk managers and senior management.
Full time employment, Monday – Friday, 40 hours per week.
MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS:
Bachelor’s degree in Mathematics, Statistics, Operations Research, or a related field and 3 years of progressive, post-baccalaureate work experience. In the alternative, will accept Master’s degree in Mathematics, Statistics, Operations Research, or related and 2 years of work experience.
Of the required experience, must have 2 years of experience in all of the following:
Experience in conducting testing or application of probability theory and statistics, stochastic calculus and differential equations, including normal distribution characteristics, error- correction models, orthogonal multivariate regression, vector auto-regression models, integration and Taylor series expansion.Experience in conducting statistical tests to analyze goodness of fit of stochastic models, including Shapiro Wilk test, Durbin Watson test, Rainbow test, VIF test, Breush-Pagan test, ADF test.Experience in CCAR stress test methodology development, including scenario expansion models and Market RWA projection models.Experience in developing VaR and Stress VaR methodologies for Agency MBS, CLO, ABS, CMBS, Corporate bonds, Municipal bonds, government bonds.Experience in conducting model testings, including correlation analysis, sensitivity analysis, stress testing and backtesting for VaR and Stress VaR models.Experience in developing computer program for statistical analysis or CCAR stress testing and VaR model testing using R, Python, SQL, VBA, Tableau and Polypaths.Experience in writing model documentation that meets regulatory expectations with SR-11-7 guidelines published by the Fed, and presentations for senior management (MD or VP level).Experience in interaction with internal validation team, internal audit team or external regulators in resolving issues for models.
Certification: FRM, CFA (at least level I)
Telecommuting: telecommuting permitted up to 40%
Travel: International travel required up to 5%; Domestic travel required up to 5%
Any suitable combination of education, training, or experience is acceptable.
The base salary for this job is $126,100 per year. This salary does not include other elements of total compensation, including a discretionary bonus and benefits such as a 401(k) program with company-matching contributions; health, dental, vision, life and disability insurance; and paid time-off plan.

 Drives RBC’s high performance culture Enables collective achievement of our strategic goals Generates sustainable shareholder returns and above market shareholder value

Job Title
Senior Counsel, Global Procurement
Job Description
What is the opportunity?
As a Senior Counsel, you will be a key member of the Global Procurement Legal Team. You will provide advice and guidance to Royal Bank of Canada and its global subsidiaries with respect to third party transactions, with an emphasis on technology and other intellectual property licensing transactions. You will also provide advice to business and functional partners on contract interpretation, legal risks and mitigation strategies associated with third party transactions.
Open to a remote working arrangement across the United States.
What will you do? 
Advise RBC and its subsidiaries with respect to structuring and documenting complex third party transactions involving technology and non-technology products, intellectual property licensing, information systems and services (including software, SaaS and data license agreements, cloud services, professional services, outsourcing arrangements, telecom arrangements, subscription and market data service agreements, etc.);Provide efficient, and timely advice and assistance to business and functional partners involving complex third party transactions and contracts (i.e. structuring; strategy; contract negotiation, drafting and management, contract interpretation, etc.);Advise business and functional units on contract interpretation, legal risks and mitigation strategies associated with third party contracts, and general supplier engagement and relationship issues, among other issues;Partner with RBC’s centers of governance (e.g., Privacy; Intellectual Property; Information Technology Risk; Tax) to develop and update RBC’s requirements for third parties and third party contracts, ensuring such requirements are consistent with applicable laws, regulations and regulatory guidance and aligned with market standards and best practices;Provide legal expertise on transactional law (e.g., privacy, intellectual property, cybersecurity and data protection, consumer protection); stay abreast of applicable third party and transactional laws, regulations and guidance; and provide training to business and functional partners as needed;Perform legal research and draft memoranda of law, as required;Assist in the development and ongoing refinement of RBC’s third party templates; andPerform/assist on special projects as needed.

Must-have 
Law degree (LLB or JD) from a recognized law school; admitted to practice law in the US;5+ years’ experience in corporate commercial contract drafting and negotiating at a top tier law firm or major corporation;Strong foundational knowledge of substantive third party commercial laws and terms (e.g., confidentiality; indemnities; limitations of liability; intellectual property) and financial services laws as they relate to third parties (e.g., privacy/cybersecurity, anti-money laundering, consumer banking); andAbility to analyze legal risk in context of business realities

In-house experience at a large, multi-national bank or diversified financial institution;Strong communication skills (written and verbal) and ability to build relationships across multiple areas of the business;Ability to work with a high degree of autonomy, handle large volumes of work and balance competing demands; andContinuous improvement mindset

Jobs.Title: 2024 Capital Markets, Global Investment Banking Summer Associate
Jobs.Description:
Come Work with Us!
At RBC, our culture is deeply supportive and rich in opportunity and reward. You will help our clients thrive and our communities prosper, empowered by a spirit of shared purpose.
Whether you’re helping clients find new opportunities, developing new technology, or providing expert advice to internal partners, you will be doing work that matters in the world, in an environment built on teamwork, service, responsibility, diversity, and integrity.
Job Title
2024 Capital Markets, Global Investment Banking Summer Associate
Job Description
Global Investment Banking Summer Associate – San Francisco
What is the opportunity?
RBC Capital Markets is a premier investment bank that provides a focused set of products and services to corporations, institutional investors and governments around the world. With more than 7,100 professionals, we operate out of 70 offices in 15 countries across North America, the U.K., Europe, and the Asia-Pacific region.
We work with clients in over 100 countries around the world to deliver the expertise and execution required to raise capital, access markets, mitigate risk and acquire or dispose of assets. We are consistently ranked among the largest global investment banks according to Bloomberg and Dealogic.
RBC Capital Markets is part of a leading provider of financial services, Royal Bank of Canada (RBC). Operating since 1869, RBC is one of the top 15 largest banks in the world and the fifth largest in North America, as measured by market capitalization. With a strong capital base and consistent financial performance, RBC is among a small group of highly rated global banks.
RBCCM U.S. Summer Associate Program
Each year, we invite rising second-year MBA students to join our Global Investment Banking (GIB) platform for a 10-week U.S. Summer Associate Program. The program provides an opportunity for you to experience the culture and atmosphere of RBC Capital Markets and experience the role of a full-time Associate.
What will you do?
GIB provides a complete suite of strategic advisory services, as well as equity and debt capital raising capabilities for leading corporations, institutions and governments. RBC Capital Markets’ investment banking platform focuses on nine core industries and seven product groups. Our San Francisco office recruits for the following industry and product groups:
Industry Group:
Technology
Product Group:
Mergers & Acquisitions (M&A)
Similar to full-time GIB Associates, Summer Associates will spend their time:
Working on a variety of live transactions and client-facing business development initiatives in all areas of GIBDeveloping and preserving complex financial modelsContributing to the delivery of client meetings and presentationsConducting research to analyze market trendsResearching and analyzing future opportunities
What do you need to succeed?
In selecting Summer Associates, we look for the following:

Jobs.Title: Trade Surveillance Analyst
Jobs.Description:
Come Work with Us!
At RBC, our culture is deeply supportive and rich in opportunity and reward. You will help our clients thrive and our communities prosper, empowered by a spirit of shared purpose.
Whether you’re helping clients find new opportunities, developing new technology, or providing expert advice to internal partners, you will be doing work that matters in the world, in an environment built on teamwork, service, responsibility, diversity, and integrity.
Job Title
Trade Surveillance Analyst
Job Description
What is the Opportunity?
Our US Trade Surveillance Analysts perform second line of defense trade monitoring for firm and client trading activity to detect potential market abuse/manipulation practices for RBC Wealth Management. To do this we utilize surveillance tools and internal systems to research alerts generated across different asset classes including but not limited to Fixed Income, Futures and Equities. We are looking for someone who has a strong analytical background and research capabilities to analyze large amounts of trading data and exhibit strong written and verbal communication skills to engage compliance, traders, and business supervisors to discuss potential issues.
What will you do?
Evaluate and explore surveillance methodologies used by the Trade Surveillance team to optimize and partner with IT and Advisory teams to maximize the efficiency of current reviewsReview model calibrations to determine the optimal mix of tuning and configuration to mitigate as much risk as possible while minimizing false positives (alert efficiency)Continue developing in-depth knowledge of financial markets and stay informed of regulatory changes and maintain subject matter expertise on surveillance industry trends and technology developmentHandle multiple projects, perform surveillance and deliver tasks in a timely manner.Review trading data emanating from multiple front-end trading systems, technology and third party vendor systems and inform relevant compliance and legal folks of any suspicious activity or patterns of unusual tradingProvide support to targeted reviews in response to inquiries from Compliance, Legal, or Human Resources personnel; Interpret and investigate substantive findings for context and potential impact
What do you need to succeed?
Must-have
Minimum of 2-5 years of experience in the brokerage industry, providing familiarity with securities industry regulatory environment, practices and operationsIn-depth knowledge of the rules and regulations governing the securities industryStrong analytical and investigative skillsSolid verbal and written communication skills
Nice-to-have
Series 7 and 63 preferred not required
What’s in it for you?
We thrive on the challenge to be our best, progressive thinking to keep growing, and working together to deliver trusted advice to help our clients thrive and communities prosper. We care about each other, reaching our potential, making a difference to our communities, and achieving success that is mutual.
A comprehensive Total Rewards Program including bonuses and flexible benefits, competitive compensation, commissions, and stock where applicableLeaders who support your development through coaching and managing opportunitiesAbility to make a difference and lasting impactWork in a dynamic, collaborative, progressive, and high-performing teamOpportunities to do challenging workOpportunities to building close relationships with clients
Job Summary
Conducts monitoring and surveillance activities to ensure business unit is in compliance with programs to prevent or identify illegal, unethical, or improper business practices. Applies experience and seasoned knowledge, skills, and practices to perform a variety of assignments.

Job Title
Associate Director, Compliance
Job Description
What is the opportunity?
Reporting directly to the Chief Compliance Officer, this role will lead Compliance’s coverage of all digital wealth management issues, including the use and governance of artificial intelligence, and serve as a key leader for escalations from Compliance oversight functions, including from the surveillance function.
What will you do?
Provide leadership and Compliance coverage for how the firm uses digital wealth management enablement tools, including CRM applications, electronic communications, digital signatures, electronic records, wealth planning tools and related technologies. Proactively engage with business partners to support new rule management, policy development, regulatory issues and initiatives, compliance risk assessments, evaluation of external events in compliance with regulatory expectations (Primarily FINRA and SEC), technology developments and RBC’s brand, reputation, and risk appetite.Collaborate with Compliance, Legal, Risk, and business colleagues to enhance the firm’s control environment, supervisory framework, policies and procedures, training, surveillance, monitoring and testing, including specific collaboration with Surveillance management and team to enhance the surveillance program for the wealth management businesses.Develop and deliver reporting and presentation materials.Provide risk oversight, including the timely risk identification, communication and management of risks and initiatives within RBC Wealth Management Compliance coverage area.Act as Problem-Solver and tailor solutions to business strategy consistent with regulations typically inclusive of FINRA and SEC rules and guidanceBe a connector that builds relationships within Compliance and with key stakeholders at all levels of the business.
What do you need to succeed?
Strong ability to evaluate laws, regulations, regulatory guidance and enforcement actions for applicability and determine necessary controls to manage regulatory riskInquisitive and analytical thinker, who is quick to spot issues and summarize for maximum impactPractical solutioningAbility to collaborate and reach common ground
Must-have
10 years’ experience in Compliance, legal, or risk at a broker-dealer or investment adviser or in related work at a law firm, regulator, consultant or similar experienceBachelor’s degreeExcellent written and verbal communication skillsStrong interest in how technological can enhance the wealth management business and its control environmentMS Office
Nice-to-have
Series 24 registeredAdvanced degreeExperience with a securities industry regulator, prosecutor’s office, or similarWealth management technology experiencePublic speaking and presentation experience

Job Summary
 The purpose of this role is to provide regulatory and compliance risk oversight and guidance to RBC Wealth Management’s Compliance and business management related to its digital strategy, related enablement tools and the control and supervisory functions. This includes the Private Client Group’s key technologies including Salesforce and topics including electronic communications, digital signatures, electronic records and strategic initiatives, including use and governance of artificial intelligence in providing wealth management services.
